Re ''Gonzales's Testimony Satisfied at Least One Person, His Boss'' (front page, April 24):
President Bush's reaction to Alberto R. Gonzales's Congressional testimony is yet another appalling and unfathomable position of this president.
The attorney general of the United States must not have even the appearance of impropriety.

The facts are clear that this attorney general has fallen well short of that standard. How can we expect our citizens to respect the law, pay their taxes and tell the truth when the nation's senior lawyer can bend the rules so easily?
The Republicans, who claimed ownership of morality, are morally bankrupt when truth and honesty mean so little compared with ''loyalty.''
James P. Tuthill Lafayette, Calif., April 24, 2007
The writer is an adjunct professor at the University of San Francisco School of Law.
